ZIF-7@carbon composites as multifunctional interlayer for rapid and durable Li-S performance Xingbo Wang a 1 Yan Zhao b 1 Feichao Wu a ⁎ Shuming Liu a Zisheng Zhang a c Zhaoyang Tan a Xiaohang Du a ⁎ Jingde Li a ⁎ a Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Chemical Process Safety, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving Tianjin Key Laboratory of Chemical Process Safety School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China Hebei Provincial Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Technology and High Efficient Energy Saving, Tianjin Key Laboratory of Chemical Process Safety, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China c Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON K1N 6N5, Canada Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering University of Ottawa Ottawa ON K1N 6N5 Canada Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON K1N 6N5, Canada ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract A multifunctional interlayer of ZIF-7 sheets vertically grown on carbon cloth (ZIF-7@CC) was developed as efficient polysulfide barrier for lithium-sulfur batteries. The notorious “shuttle effect” of polysulfide during charge–discharge process induces grievous capacity fading, while the sluggish polysulfide conversion kinetics significantly hinders the development of practically viable lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. In this study, a novel ZIF-7@carbon composite with ZIF-7 sheets vertically rooted on carbon cloth was developed as multifunctional interlayer to address these issues. The composite shows directional layered structure with outstanding compactness, and thus can provide massive active sites for accelerated redox reactions. The pore channels are perpendicular to the square surface, resulting in extremely high utilization of one-dimensional channels. Therefore, this structure can not only maintain the structural stability during the charge–discharge process by providing enough space for volume expansion, but also contribute to efficient exposure and utilization of active sites for the physical/chemical adsorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfide. As a result, Li-S batteries with the as-developed interlayer deliver a considerable areal capacity of 4.75 mAh cm−2 at an elevated sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2, and an impressive cyclability with an extremely low capacity-fading rate of merely 0.04% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1C. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Interlayer ZIF-7 sheets High sulfur loading 1 Introduction In the past few years, with the ever-growing energy requirements for portable energy storage equipment and grid storage, people have been exploring for high energy density batteries [1]. Among diverse types of energy storage facilities, Li-S batteries stand out by reason of their high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), significantly superior to conventional lithium-ion batteries [1,2]. Nevertheless, the commercialization of Li-S battery is severely restricted by several intrinsic technical challenges, covering low conductivity of sulfur, unsatisfactorily volume expansion during the lithiation/delithiation processes, and the generation of soluble intermediate discharge product lithium polysulfide (LiPS, Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8), etc [3,4]. Specially, the dissolved LiPS species are likely to migrate across the separator from the cathode to the anode, and then to be further reduced to the insoluble precipitation Li2S2/Li2S on the lithium surface, namely the notorious “shuttle effect”. This process always leads to a consumption of active materials, the deterioration of coulombic efficiency and unsatisfied cycling performance [5–7]. Various attempts have been made to solve these problems, among which the most competitive one is the elaborated design of functional interlayers [8,9]. Until now, scores of nanostructure materials including non-polar carbons material, polar inorganics material, and their composites have been developed as interlayer candidates based on their strong physical or/and chemical adsorption, as well as fast electrocatalytic conversion of LiPS [10–12]. Among them, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have become considerably popular to be applied as functional materials to construct interlayers for suppressing the polysulfide shuttling, for the purpose of employing their unique porosity, large surface area and structure flexibility [13,14]. These interlayers show good performance in inhibiting the polysulfide shuttling and enhancing cycling stabilities of Li-S batteries. Unfortunately, most MOFs are in powder form with poor electrical conductivity, so it is not uncommon that MOFs require combining with non-reactive conductive materials and binder or pyrolysis into carbons and metal oxides when applied in Li-S batteries [15,16]. The introduced inert materials would unavoidably decrease energy density and cause extra “sulfur loss”, while carbonization at a high temperature would damage the inherent molecular active sites and the regular pore structure of pristine MOFs to a greater or lesser extent [16,17]. Hence, there is still an urgent need to rationally design novel MOFs-based interlayers for highly effective LiPS barrier. In this work, densified ZIF-7 sheets were directly grown on carbon cloth (CC) (abbreviations ZIF-7@CC) as a multifunctional interlayer material for Li-S batteries. A facile chemical vapor deposition (CVD) process was conducted to prepare ZIF-7 sheets using ZnO nanorods as the metal source. The unique directional layered structure of ZIF-7 sheets can provide massive active sites for accelerated redox reactions. Besides, the one-dimensional micropore channels that are perpendicular to the square surface also contribute to the exposure and utilization of interaction sites. Based on these advantages, efficient exposure and full accessibility of adsorptive and electrocatalytic sites can be achieved, which ensures strong LiPS adsorption for efficient sulfur immobilization and effective electrocatalysis conversion of LiPS. Consequently, the as-synthesized ZIF-7@CC interlayer forms a barrier that can prevent LiPS from passing through the separator and inhibit the shuttle effect. Meanwhile, the reaction kinetics of LiPS conversion is also improved by the electrocatalytic effect of ZIF-7 sheets. Consequently, thanks to these aforementioned advantages, the Li-S battery with ZIF-7@CC interlayer exhibits an impressive cyclic stability with a very limited capacity decay of 0.04% at 1 C for 500 cycles, and the area capacity can reach 4.75 mAh cm−2 in the case of raised sulfur loading. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of reduced graphene oxide/sulfur Reduced graphene oxide/sulfur (rGO/S) was synthesized employing a melting-diffusion approach, which was the cathode active material of the Li-S battery. Firstly, 45 mL graphene oxide (GO) solution was uniformly dispersed by ultrasonic treatment. Secondly, 0.4 g m-xylene was dissolved in 15 mL water, and then heated and stirred at 50 °C for 20 min. Finally, the above two solutions were mixed with each other and stirred for 10 min, sonicated for 30 min, and then put into the reactor for hydrothermal reaction at a temperature of 180 °C. The prepared rGO and S were mixed to grind (mass ratio is 1:3), and carbon disulfide (CS2) was dripped during the grinding process, followed by ventilated in the glove box and finally heated in a hydrothermal kettle at 155 °C for 12 h. 2.2 Preparation of ZnO@CC Before fabrication, the carbon cloth with a thickness of 0.31 mm need to be cut into a 19 mm-diameter disc and washed with 10% nitric acid, ethanol and distilled water for 30 minutes in sequence, and then dried for 2 h at a temperature of 80 °C. After that, a 2.83 cm2 carbon cloth was soaked in 0.27 mmol L−1 Zn(Ac)2·2H2O/ethanol solution for 4 times and then annealed at 350 °C in air for 2 h [18]. Then, the handled carbon cloth was placed vertically in a beaker and immersed into a precursor solution containing 0.744 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.35 g hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), which was then heated in water-bath at 95 °C for 6 h [19]. Next, the product was flushed with ethanol, and finally dried at 50 °C for 10 h, which are denoted as ZnO@CC. 2.3 Preparation of ZIF-7@CC ZIF-7@CC was synthesized by a facile CVD process. Benzimidazole (BIm) powders (2 g) were directly put at the bottom of a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and ZnO@CC was placed vertically above BIm powders without contact with BIm powders [20]. Then, the autoclave was heated in an electric heating constant temperature drying oven at 190 °C for 11 h to prepare ZIF-7 sheets through vapor phase transformation [20]. After crystallization, ZIF-7@CC was rinsed by methanol, and dried overnight at 30 °C. 2.4 Preparation of LiPS solution Sulfur powder and lithium sulfide in a 5:1 molar ratio were added into the electrolyte, which was composed of bis (trifluoromethane) sulfonamide lithium salt (LiTFSI, 1 M), 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME)/1,3-dioxolane (DOL) (the volume ratio was 1:1) and lithium nitrate (LiNO3, 0.1 M). The mixture was stirred in a glove box under Ar atmosphere at 50 °C for 24 h, and the LiPS solution would be obtained, in which the molar concentration of LiPS was 0.1 M. 2.5 Material characterization X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Brukerm, D8) system alongside with Cu Kα radiation was used to test the crystalline structures of materials. The microstructures of relevant specimens were tested by scanning electron microscope (SEM, JSM-7100F, JEOL) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM2100F, JEOL). A Thermal Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer was utilized to record the X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the ZIF-7@CC samples. The specific surface areas and pore size distribution of the materials were determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the N2 adsorption–desorption experiment. The UV–Vis spectra were obtained by a Cary 60 UV–Vis spectrophotometer within the scope of 250–800 nm. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements rGO/S, Super P and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binders based on the 8:1:1 mass ratio were dispersed in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) to form a slurry, and then coated on Al foil with an areal sulfur-loading of 2.1 mg cm−1. The above slurry-coated Al foil need being cut to10 mm diameter discs to be used as the cathode of Li-S battery. Next, the whole battery was assembled in a glove box in which the contents of H2O and O2 were lower than 0.01 ppm, and the assembly involved cathode, interlayer, Celgard separator, lithium foil and electrolyte. The electrolyte consisted of 1.0 M LiTFSI in DOL and DME (the volume ratio was 1:1) with 0.1 M LiNO3. Each battery needed to drop 40 μL of electrolyte. The constant current discharge/charge test was conducted at room temperature on a Neware battery cycler and the voltage range was 1.7–2.8 V. An electrochemical workstation (Corrtest, CS235OH) was selected to test the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of Li-S batteries. 2.7 Theoretical calculations The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were implemented by the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP), in which all the models used adopt periodic boundary conditions [21]. The adsorption energies (E ads) are calculated to evaluate the adsorption strength of LiPS on ZIF-7 surface employing the following formula [22,23]: E ads = E total - E LiPS - E ZIF 7 where E total is the total energy, E LiPS represents the energy of LiPS, and E ZIF-7 stands for the energy of the ZIF-7 surface. As can be seen from the above equation, a more negative value of E ads indicates the reaction between LiPS and the ZIF-7 surface are more likely to occur (exothermic reaction). 3 Results and discussion The general fabrication process of ZIF-7@CC interlayer is shown in Fig. 1 . Simply, ZnO-nanorods were firstly synthesized on carbon cloth by solvothermal growth in a water bath, and then exposed to BIm vapor to convert the ZnO-nanorods into ZIF-7 sheets via the CVD approach. The pristine CC presents a crisscrossed fibrous frame-work and the surface is fairly smooth, which is presented in Fig. S1(a) in the Supporting Information. Obviously, as displayed in Fig. 2 (a), ZnO nanorods are uniformly formed on the CC after the water bath treatment. While, through the CVD treatment, the sample exhibits clear morphological changes compared with pristine ZnO nanorods, turning from needle-like to plate-like structure (Fig. 2a–c). As shown in Fig. 2(c), the sheets seem like cuboids with square planar grid structure which are consistent with the morphologies of ZIF-7 sheets reported in the literatures [24–26]. Besides, these ZIF-7 sheets are entirely and compactly aligned with a face perpendicular to the CC, demonstrating a perfect orientation. What’s more, it is evident that ZnO nanorods served as the Zn sources for the epitaxial growth of ZIF-7 sheets, which can also be proved by the XPS survey spectrum in Fig. S2. From the overall morphology of transmission map in Fig. 2(d), the ZIF-7 sheets overlap partly or entirely with each other, forming stacked sheets, which match well with the SEM images in Fig. 2(b–c). Fig. S1(b) shows the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image and selected area diffraction of ZIF-7@CC. Surprisingly, the HRTEM image shows that the material seems amorphous, which is inconsistent with the result presented in the XRD patterns that ZIF-7 sheet has a crystal structure (Fig. 3 a). This may be related to high energy irradiation damage of ZIF-7 structure [27]. Besides, the elemental mapping analysis of ZIF-7@CC in Fig. 2(e) demonstrates the coexistence of N, Zn, C and O elements, which are homogeneously distributed. Crystalline structures of the samples were determined by the XRD tests and the results are displayed in Fig. 3(a). The peaks of initial ZnO nanorods well correspond to standard ZnO PDF cards (JCPDS No. 36–1451), while the decrease of ZnO peaks around 32.1°, 34.7° and 36.7° confirms the consumption of ZnO nanorods for the growth of ZIF-7 sheets. The emergence of XRD peaks around 9°, 16.7° and 20° for ZIF-7@CC compared with pure ZIF-7 demonstrates the successful formation of ZIF-7- sheets with highly orientated ZIF-7-III phases on CC, which corresponds well to the SEM images shown in Fig. 2(b and c) [24–26]. This MOF possesses unique layered structure and densely arranged one-dimensional micropore channels, which makes it expected to realize the fully exposure and utilization of adsorptive and catalytic sites when employed in Li-S batteries [24–26,28,29]. Besides, the XRD patterns can evidently illustrate the evolution of ZnO nanorods transforming into ZIF-7 sheets, and the broad peak near 25° for ZIF-7@CC is attributed to the (002) reflection of CC. Fig. 3(b) and Fig. S3 summarize the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution of ZIF-7@CC and ZnO@CC, respectively. The calculated specific surface area of the ZIF-7@CC is about 87 m2 g−1, while the calculated specific surface area of the ZnO@CC is only 17.25 m2 g−1, indicating a stronger adsorption capacity of ZIF-7@CC than that of ZnO@CC. The pore size distribution of ZIF-7@CC displayed in Fig. 3(b) shows that this material possesses not only mesopores but also large pores as well. The relatively larger holes may be attributed to the stacked gaps and channels between ZIF-7 sheets (Fig. S1c), while the smaller pores are likely originated from the mesoporous structure of MOFs itself, which can be judged from the TEM image in Fig. S1(d) [9,30,31]. This hierarchical structure is expected to effectively mitigate the volume expansion when charging and discharging, and supply more active sites for sulfur adsorption and redox reaction [32,33]. The FT-IR spectrum in Fig. 3(c) shows the signals of ZIF-7@CC, in which the asymmetric stretching vibration (C = C, 1470 cm−1) and the out-of-plane bending vibration (C–H, 742 cm−1) are consistent with literatures [34,35]. In addition, the Zn-N bond appears at 428 cm−1. Fig. 3(d–f) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of Zn 2p, C 1s and N 1s for ZIF-7@CC, respectively [36]. The Zn 2p spectrum in Fig. 3(d) has two distinctive peaks at 1021.61 and 1044.73 eV, respectively, and these two peaks can be assigned to the Zn-O bond of unreacted ZnO nano-rods, which matches well with the truth indicated by the XRD pattern in Fig. 3(a) that ZnO was not completely consumed [37,38]. Fig. 3(e) displays the C 1s spectrum and the peaks at 291.85 eV, 285.54 eV and 284.53 eV belong to CN bond, CO/CN bond and CH/CC bond, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 3(f) that there are two fitted peaks in the N 1s spectrum. Wherein, the peak at 399.05 eV belongs to N-C and the peak at 399.74 eV corresponds to N-Zn [25]. In order to explore the important role of ZIF-7@CC interlayer in the electrochemical improvement of lithium-sulfur battery, different interlayers and no interlayer batteries were assembled and evaluated. Fig. 4 (a) displays the first two laps CV curves of the Li-S cell with ZIF-7@CC interlayer. During the discharge process, the two reduction peaks at 2.31 V and 1.96 V (vs. Li+/Li) suggest that the elemental sulfur is reduced to soluble long-chain LiPS and then further into insoluble and insulating short-chain Li2S2/Li2S, respectively [39]. In the subsequent charging process, the peak at 2.50 V corresponds to the oxidation of sulfur. In addition, the CV curve shows good coincidence for different cycles, suggesting the high electrochemical reversibility. The galvanostatic charge–discharge curves of the cell at 0.2 C are presented in Fig. 4(b), and two discharging and one charging plateaus can be discerned, which well match with the CV results in the light of the multistep sulfur reaction mechanism. Besides, it is worth noting that a similar voltage difference in the first cycle and 100 cycle can be observed, indicating its facilitated redox reaction and excellent electrochemical stability. Fig. 4(c) summarizes the cyclic performance of Li-S cells with different interlayers. The cell with ZIF-7@CC interlayer exhibits the highest initial capacity of 1168 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C, compared with the other two Li-S cells with ZnO@CC interlayer (1030 mAh g−1) and no interlayer (798 mAh g−1), suggesting the significantly increased sulfur utilization. What’s more, a relatively high capacity retention of 77% and stable coulomb efficiency of nearly 100% over 100 cycles can be obtained by introducing ZIF-7@CC interlayer, strongly confirming its excellent cycling stability. The significant improvement in cycle performance of the battery with ZIF-7@CC interlayer may lie partly a result of the strong physical and chemical interaction of ZIF-7 sheets with LiPS, which greatly assists in preventing LiPS from passing through the separator, and thus is capable of restraining the shuttle effect effectively [40]. Rate performance of Li-S battery with ZIF-7@CC interlayer reveals the high initial discharge specific capacities of 1159, 997, 945, 888, 817 and 660 mAh g−1 under different current densities of 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5C, respectively, greatly superior to the performances of the cells with ZnO@CC and without interlayer, just as shown in Fig. 4(d). Even increasing the current density to 5C, an admirable capacity of 660 mAh g−1 of the cell with ZIF-7@CC interlayer can still be obtained, which is equivalent to 57% of the original capacity. In addition, when one switched the current density back to 0.2 C, the specific capacity returns to 91% of the initial capacity, demonstrating that the Li-S cell with ZIF-7@CC interlayer has excellent electrochemical reversibility. By contrast, the batteries with ZnO@CC interlayer and with no interlayer show extremely poor rate performance and maintain a specific capacity of merely 369 and 267 mAh g−1 at 5C, respectively. The above results suggest that the ZIF-7@CC interlayer exhibits outstanding rate capability, which may result from the enhanced charge transfer dynamics and the accelerated redox reaction kinetics. Fig. 4(e) shows the charge–discharge curves of the Li-S battery with ZIF-7@CC interlayer at different rates, and it still demonstrates distinctive charge and discharge plateaus at high current density of 5C. However, the batteries with ZnO@CC interlayer and without interlayer exhibit considerably serious electrochemical polarization and have large potential difference at high rates, which can be obtained in Fig. S4. This information further suggests the high performance of ZIF-7@CC interlayer in promoting sulfur redox reaction. In order to further prove the advantages of the proposed ZIF-7@CC interlayer, the EIS measurements for Li-S batteries with different interlayers before and after cycling experiments were carried out. As presented in Fig. 4(f), the EIS spectrum before cycling shows that the charge transfer resistance of Li-S battery containing ZIF-7@CC interlayer is obviously reduced, which indicates its favored charge transfer process for fast reaction kinetics. What’s more, there are two semicircles in the EIS for the batteries with ZnO@CC interlayer and no interlayer after cycling (Fig. S5), which is in striking contrast with their EIS before the cycles (Fig. 4f). And this result is mainly due to the unsatisfactory interface contact resistance of insulating Li2S or Li2S2 deposited on the lithium anode during the cycles [41–43]. On the contrast, the EIS for ZIF-7@CC retains a semicircle, indicating that the developed interlayer can effectively restrain the shuttle effect of LiPS and reduce the deposition of Li-S solid on the lithium anode, which makes it an excellent sandwich material for Li-S batteries. Long-term cycling experiments were conducted at 1 C to evaluate the synergy effects of physicochemical adsorption and electrocatalysis towards LiPS. As shown in Fig. 4(g), the Li-S cell with ZIF-7@CC interlayer displays a first discharge capacity of 894 mAh g−1, and the discharge capacity declines to 542 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, along with a small capacity fading of 0.04% per cycle. As a contrast, the batteries with ZnO@CC and no interlayer show pitiable capacities of 397 and 120 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles, respectively. The smallest capacity fading of ZIF-7@CC interlayer demonstrates its excellent long cycle performance. Besides, as shown in Fig. 4(h), when increasing the sulfur loading to 5.5 mg cm−2, the battery with ZIF-7@CC shows a high area capacity of 4.75 mAh cm−2, enough to prove its good cycling stability. These results further confirm the great advantages of the proposed ZIF-7@CC interlayer. For better understanding the advtanges of ZIF-7@CC interlayer and determining whether it is related to adsorption and the acceleration of electrochemical kinetics, visual adsorption experiments were carried out by adding ZIF-7@CC, ZnO@CC and rGO to the prepared LiPS solution [44]. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the solution of LiPS containing the ZIF-7@CC becomes colorless after 3 h. By contrast, the color fades only slightly in the reference solution containing ZnO@CC, and there is almost no color change in the solution with rGO. Then, the samples were tested by UV–Vis and the results further reveal that ZIF-7@CC have strong adsorption capacities for LiPS compared with ZnO@CC and rGO. The characteristic adsorption peaks of LiPS at 231 and 273 nm decrease after adding ZIF-7@CC as shown in Fig. 5(b). Aiming at further proving the adsorption of LiPS in theory, DFT calculation was carried out. Fig. 5(c) shows the most stable configurations of LiPS adsorption on ZIF-7, and the corresponding adsorption energies of Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4 and Li2S2 are calculated as −1.15, −0.95, −1.07, and −1.08 eV, respectively, which indicates the relatively strong interaction between ZIF-7 and LiPS [45,46]. The results are enough to confirm that ZIF-7@CC interlayer can effectively fix LiPS through the adsorption of ZIF-7 sheets towards LiPS. To adequately measure the chemical interaction between the ZIF-7@CC and LiPS, XPS analysis was tested on the pure LiPS and the ZIF-7@CC interlayer after the long-term cycling experiment, with results presented in Fig. 6 (a–c). As displayed in Fig. 6(a), the peak at 55.3 eV can be assigned to Li spectrum of LiPS, demonstrating the formation of the Li-S bond. After the adsorption of LiPS, a new Li-N/O bond peak appeared at 55.5 eV of ZIF-7@CC, indicating the formation of lithium bonds. In addition, Fig. 6(b) shows that the S 2p spectra of LiPS have two peaks at 161.3 and 162.8 eV, respectively, which are caused by terminal sulfur (ST −1) and bridge sulfur (SB 0), respectively [47,48]. After the cycling experiment, these peaks move to a higher binding energy range, indicating that the electron transfer between polysulfides and metal center and the formation of Zn/Li-S structure bring about a decrease in the electron cloud density. In addition, a new characteristic peak at 160.9 eV emerges in LiPS@ZIF-7@CC, corresponding to Zn-S bonds. After ZIF-7@CC adsorption, a pair of new peaks can be observed at 167.23 and 168.62 eV, respectively, which indicates the formation of thiosulfate and sulfate species. And this result can be due to the sulfur oxidation by ZIF-7 sheets, which is beneficial to sulfur confinement following a sulfur incorporation mechanism [9,49]. Besides, Fig. 6(c) shows the high-resolution XPS spectra of Zn 2p for ZIF-7@CC, and the two peaks at 1021.61/1020.96 and 1044.73/1044.08 eV belong to the Zn 2p 3/2 and Zn 2p 1/2, respectively [50,51]. After cycling experiment, these two Zn-O peaks are wholly down-shifted by 0.65 eV, suggesting the formation of Zn-S bond [50–52]. This matches well with S 2p XPS spectra presented in Fig. 6(b). In order to prove the viewpoints above, visual permeation tests of LiPS were conducted in a H-type cell. As can be found from Fig. 6(d), the cell containing routine PP separator presents a dark brown color in the opposite cavity, making it clear that serious LiPS penetration happened. While, the opposite cavity well keeps a transparent solution when euqipped with ZIF-7@CC interlayer, which is a firm evidence that the interlayer possesses an outstanding capability of blocking LiPS. Importantly, the unique layered structure and the densely arranged one-dimensional micropore channels of ZIF-7 sheets offer enough adsorptive sites for the LiPS, which contributes to establish a barrier that significantly restrains the shuttling effect. Fig. 6(e) displays a schematic diagram of the ZIF-7@CC interlayer, and the migrated polysulfides can be captured on the side of the ZIF-7@CC interlayer. In order to explore whether the advantage of ZIF-7@CC is related to kinetics, lithium ion diffusion and electrochemical catalysis were tested. The diffusion coefficient of lithium ion (D Li) was tested first, as it is widely used to reflect the transportation of Li ions. CV tests of the Li-S cells with ZIF-7@CC, ZnO@CC and no-interlayer at diverse scan speed of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 mV s−1 were carried out and the D Li values were calculated by the following Randles-Sevcik equation [53–57]: I peak = 2.69 × 10 5 × n 3 2 × A × D L i 1 2 × C Li + × v 1 2 where the I peak is the amperes (A), n presents the electron number involved in the reaction process (here n = 2), A is the electrode area (A = 0.78 cm2), ν is the scanning speed (mV s−1), and C Li+ is the concentration of Li ions in electrolyte. The results are presented in Fig. 7 , Fig. S6 and Table S1. As shown in Fig. 7(a–c), the anodic and cathodic peaks are linear to the square root of the scanning speed, and the slopes of the curves are positively correlated with the corresponding lithium ion diffusion. According to the slopes of the obtained fitting line (Fig. 7d–f), the Li-ion diffusion coefficients were computed and the results are presented in Tab. S1. At peak A, the Li-ion diffusion coefficients for Li-S batteries with ZIF-7@CC, ZnO@CC and no-interlayer are 3.2 × 10−7, 8.1 × 10−8 and 5.49 × 10−8 cm2 s−1, respectively. In peak B, the Li-ion diffusion coefficients were 2.36 × 10−7, 6.3 × 10−8 and 3.05 × 10−9 cm2 s−1, respectively, and the Li-ion diffusion coefficients are 7.18 × 10−8, 2.75 × 10−8, and 1.33 × 10−8 cm2 s−1 in peak C, respectively. Compared with the battery with no interlayer and the battery with ZnO@CC interlayer, the use of ZIF-7@CC interlayer significantly improves the lithium ion diffusion coefficient, rendering the accelerated transportation of Li ions. These results indicate that the Li-S battery with ZIF-7@CC interlayer has excellent electrochemical performance, decent conductivity and strong polysulfide trapping ability to realize fast and reliable Li-S performance. The developed ZIF-7@CC is also a good catalyst to accelerate the catalytic conversion of S, and its mechanism is shown in Fig. 8 (a). In order to prove conversion kinetics of the interlayer, we assembled the symmetrical cell with ZIF-7@CC, ZnO@CC, and rGO as the same electrodes, and the LiPS solution was the same with that employed in the LiPS adsorption experiment. It can be distinctly discerned from Fig. 8(b) that the cell with ZIF-7@CC displays the largest redox current response and smallest potential hysteresis, which further confirms its decent catalytic effect. In addition, LSV tests of ZIF-7@CC, ZnO@CC and rGO were performed in a 0.1 M Li2S/methanol electrolyte solution to evaluate their electrocatalytic oxidation activities, in which platinum wire was counter electrode and Ag/AgCl was reference electrode [58,59]. As shown in Fig. 8(c), ZIF-7@CC provides the lowest initial potential of −0.67 V at the scanning rate of 5 mV s−1, while higher values of −0.6 V and −0.58 V can be observed in ZnO@CC and rGO, respectively. Clearly, ZIF-7@CC demonstrates the highest redox reaction kinetics, confirming its excellent electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, it can be inferred that quite a lot of LiPS molecules could be depleted by catalytic conversion and also the adequate adsorption by ZIF-7 sheets when passing through the large pores of the interlayer, forming a reliable barrier to inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPS [60–62]. 4 Conclusions In summary, a novel vertically rooted ZIF-7 sheets multifunctional interlayer has been successfully designed. The unique layered structure and the densely arranged one-dimensional micropore channels of ZIF-7 sheets strengthen their physical and chemical adsorption towards polysulfides. In addition, the prepared ZIF-7@CC interlayer can function as an electrocatalyst to promote the reaction kinetics of polysulfides and increase the utilization of S. Besides, the ordered sheets structure is capable of providing buffer space for volume expansion when charging and discharging. Attributed to its structural benefits, ZIF-7@CC interlayer presents a high specific capacity at different rates and impressive long-term cycling performance with a low capacity attenuation rate of 0.04% per cycle at 1 C over 500 cycles. Our work validates the strong adsorption and catalytic conversion of LiPS on directional layered ZIF-7 material and demonstrates the capability for realizing superior Li-S performances when employing it as interlayer in Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: The notorious “shuttle effect” of polysulfide during charge–discharge process induces grievous capacity fading, while the sluggish polysulfide conversion kinetics significantly hinders the development of practically viable lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. In this study, a novel ZIF-7@carbon composite with ZIF-7 sheets vertically rooted on carbon cloth was developed as multifunctional interlayer to address these issues. The composite shows directional layered structure with outstanding compactness, and thus can provide massive active sites for accelerated redox reactions. The pore channels are perpendicular to the square surface, resulting in extremely high utilization of one-dimensional channels. Therefore, this structure can not only maintain the structural stability during the charge–discharge process by providing enough space for volume expansion, but also contribute to efficient exposure and utilization of active sites for the physical/chemical adsorption and catalytic conversion of polysulfide. As a result, Li-S batteries with the as-developed interlayer deliver a considerable areal capacity of 4.75 mAh cm−2 at an elevated sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2, and an impressive cyclability with an extremely low capacity-fading rate of merely 0.04% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1C.

coredata.dc:title: ZIF-7@carbon composites as multifunctional interlayer for rapid and durable Li-S performance
